entries.text: Socrates' elenchus operates not as rhetorical refutation but as epistemic purification, exposing contradictions embedded within unexamined beliefs.
The Apology frames philosophy as civic disturbance, situating inquiry in structural tension with democratic consensus.
Socratic irony functions as methodological destabilization rather than mere conversational modesty.
In Plato’s dialogues, Socrates’ refusal to write reinforces philosophy as dialogic praxis rather than doctrinal transmission.
Socratic moral intellectualism collapses the distinction between knowledge and virtue, positing wrongdoing as epistemic failure.
The daimonion introduces a model of negative divine guidance, restraining rather than directing action.
Socrates’ trial reveals the fragility of parrhesia within participatory democracy.
Maieutics conceptualizes philosophical inquiry as midwifery, privileging latent knowledge over imposed doctrine.
Socrates destabilizes sophistic relativism by grounding argument in universalizable definitions.
The Socratic commitment to self-examination reframes philosophy as existential discipline rather than speculative abstraction.
Socratic dialogue constructs ignorance as productive starting point rather than epistemic deficiency.
In the Crito, Socrates redefines justice as structural fidelity to legal order even under personal harm.
Socratic method foregrounds definitional rigor as prerequisite for ethical clarity.
Socrates' refusal to escape Athens transforms obedience into philosophical consistency rather than political submission.
The Gadfly metaphor positions philosophical critique as necessary irritation within civic life.
